articles.title: Y chromosome loss from immune cells may cause heart disease
articles.description: The Y chromosome, involved in sex determination, mysteriously disappears from some men’s immune cells as they get older – and that could be fatal
articles.content:
By Clare Wilson
The Y chromosome is one of two sex chromosomes in humans
Shutterstock/vchal
The immune cells of many older men lose their Y chromosomes, and this may contribute to men having a hig… [+343 chars]

articles.title: Risk of space rock collisions may limit where JWST can look in the sky
articles.description: After an unexpectedly large micrometeoroid hit one of the main mirrors on the James Webb Space Telescope, its operators are considering not pointing it in some directions to minimise future head-on collisions
articles.content:
By Leah Crane
Artist’s illustration of the James Webb Space Telescope
Adriana Manrique Gutierrez, NASA Animator

articles.title: Ancient DNA adds to evidence for Native Americans' East Asian ancestry
articles.description: Genetic analysis of a woman’s skull from 14,000 years ago found in south-west China suggests she was related to an ancient population that migrated to North America from East Asia
articles.content:
By Carissa Wong
Side view of the ancient skull unearthed from Red Dear Cave
Xueping Ji
Ancient DNA from a 14,000-year-old skull found in southwest China reveals that the individual was a member of… [+2555 chars]

articles.title: Woodpeckers don't have built-in shock absorbers to protect their brain
articles.description: It was thought that spongy bone in woodpeckers’ heads cushioned their brains from hard knocks, but in fact their skulls are stiff like a hammer
articles.content:
By Christa Lesté-Lasserre
Woodpeckers skulls aren’t built to absorb shock, but rather to deliver a harder and more efficient hit into wood.
Woodpeckers hammer their beaks onto tree trunks to commun… [+2701 chars]

articles.title: New kind of laser uses tiny particle clumps to generate light
articles.description: Lasers normally use mirrors to create laser light, but a new kind uses clumps of moving particles. The result is a laser that is more programmable and could generate extra sharp visual displays
articles.content:
By Karmela Padavic-Callaghan
A new kind of laser is more programmable than conventional ones
Getty Images/Flavio Coelho
A new kind of laser uses tiny moving particles to produce beams of light. Th… [+2228 chars]

articles.title: Jurassic World Dominion's dinosaur trafficking isn't far from reality
articles.description: The movie franchise's conclusion features black market dinosaur trading. Although it is fictional, this storyline rings alarmingly true for birds, the direct descendants of dinosaurs, warns Raj Tawney
articles.content:
By Raj Tawney
Simone Rotella

articles.title: Octopus-inspired glove lets you manipulate objects underwater
articles.description: A glove with artificial suckers inspired by those found on octopuses allows people to securely grip delicate objects underwater, and the technology could be added to robots in future
articles.content:
By Matthew Sparkes
This “octa-glove” lets you pick up objects using octopus-like suckers
Michael Bartlett

articles.title: Robot that can perceive its body has self-awareness, claim researchers
articles.description: The team claims to have given a robot self-awareness of its location in physical space, but others are sceptical

A robot has been argued to have developed an awareness of its surroundings

articles.title: Forests are becoming less resilient because of climate change
articles.description: An analysis of two decades of satellite data shows that forests in arid, tropical and temperate regions are becoming less able to bounce back after events such as drought and logging
articles.content:
By Adam Vaughan
A pine forest near Auckland, New Zealand

articles.title: Why restoring seagrass meadows would be a huge conservation win
articles.description: Seagrass meadows are vanishing at a rate of 7 per cent a year, but this is a habitat that buries carbon up to 35 times faster than tropical rainforest. We must safeguard and restore it, says Sophie Pavelle
articles.content:
By Sophie Pavelle
Michelle Durbano
SEAGRASS has been hailed both as conservation’s “wonder plant” and its “ugly duckling”. Since 1980, the world has been losing this flowering marine plant to pollu… [+416 chars]
